Detailed Description

The IOBoardClient class provides hardware independent functions to interact with the IOBoardServer to allow access to components located on the I/O board.

These generic IOBoardClient class functions are supported regardless of the I/O board used (i.e., these functions can be used with different I/O boards provided that the correct hardware server is executing). This independence with respect to the hardware allows the user to construct a singular control program that can execute with different I/O boards without the need to alter code to compensate for the change in hardware. Specifically, the IOBoardClient functions allow the user to perform the following: i) read/write to D/A and digital I/O channels, ii) read encoder channels, and iii) retrieve I/O board server specific information (e.g., the maximum/minimum D/A voltage, the number of D/A channels being used, the number if digital I/O lines available, etc.).

Example Program: 

//========================================================================
// Project: QRTS Utility Classes
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------
// Package: I/O Board Client
// Authors: Nick Costescu, Markus Loffler
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------
// File: mirror
// This program mirrors all of the analog inputs to the analog
// outputs. Hook up a signal generator to input 0, and a scope to output
// 0 and see what happens.
// You must have an IOBoardServer running to use this program.
//========================================================================

#include <unistd.h>
#include <iostream.h>
#include <sys/sched.h>
#include <stdlib.h>

#include "IOBoardClient.hpp"


//========================================================================
// main
//========================================================================

int main (int argc, char *argv[]) 
{
  int channel;
  int numAdc;
  int numDac;

  IOBoardClient *iobc;
  char *ioBoardServerName;

  // If the user supplied a command line argument, it is the name of the
  // IOBoardServer to use, else assume "iobs0"
  
  if (argc < 2)
    ioBoardServerName = "qrts/iobs0";
  else
    ioBoardServerName = argv[1];

  // Connect to the IOBoardServer 
  iobc = new IOBoardClient (ioBoardServerName);

  // Check if able to connect.
  if (iobc->isStatusError())
  {
    cerr << "Can't find IOBoard server " << ioBoardServerName;
    cerr << ", so exiting." << endl;
    return -1;
  }

  cout << "This program mirrors all of the analog inputs to the analog" << endl
       << "outputs. Hook up a signal generator to input 0, and a scope to output" << endl
       << "0 and see what happens." << endl;

  numAdc = iobc->getNumAdc ();
  numDac = iobc->getNumDac ();

  // Set up a SIGALRM signal in 10 seconds.  This will kill us since we don't
  // have a signal handler.  This may leave voltages on DAC channels.
  alarm(10);
  
  while (1) 
  {
    // Mirror the inputs to the outputs
    for (channel=0; channel<numAdc && channel<numDac; channel++)
      iobc->setDacValue(channel, iobc->getAdcValue(channel));
  }
}

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

IOBoardClient ( const char * serverName )
 

Constructor. Connects to an I/O board server.

Parameters:
serverName   Name under which the I/O board server is registered (e.g., "iobs0").

Example: 

     IOBoardClient *iobc;
     iobc = new IOBoardClient ("qrts/");

~IOBoardClient ( ) [virtual]
 

Destructor.

Example: 

     delete iobc;

Member Function Documentation

int isStatusOk ( ) [inline]
 

Checks to see if the status is OK.

Returns:
Non-zero: Status is OK
zero: Status is not OK.

Example: 

     if (iobc->isStatusOk ())
       cout << "The status is OK.";
     else
       cout << "The status is not OK." << endl;

int isStatusError ( ) [inline]
 

Checks to see if any errors have occurred.

Returns:
Non-zero if errors have occurred, zero if no errors have occurred.

Example: 

     if (iobc->isStatusError())
       cout << "An Error has occurred."<< endl;
     else
       cout << "No errors have occurred." << endl;

void setStatusOk ( ) [inline]
 

Set the status to OK. Clears all error entries from the stack. Clears the overflow and error count variables.

Returns:
None.

Example: 

     iobc->setStatusOk();

void setStatusError ( ) [inline]
 

Sets the status error flag.

Returns:
None.

Example: 

     iboc->setStatusError();

int getNumEncoders ( ) [inline]
 

Obtains the number of encoder channels available.

Returns:
Number of encoder channels being polled by the hardware server.

Example: 

     numberEncoderChannels = iobc->getNumEncoders();

int getEncoderValue ( int channel ) [inline]
 

Reads the current encoder pulse count of the specified channel.

Parameters:
channel   The encoder channel to be read.
Returns:
The current encoder pulse count.

Example: 

     encoderCount=iobc->getEncoderValue(0);

int getEncoderIndexValue ( int channel ) [inline]
 

Obtains the encoder position (count) when an index pulse is crossed. IMPORTANT: This function might not be implemented for all I/O board servers. Pleaase check the documenation of I/O board server that you are using.

Parameters:
channel   Encoder channel to be read.
Returns:
The encoder count when an index pulse is crossed.

Example: 

     indexPosition=iobc->getEncoderIndexValue(0);

void setEncoderValue ( int channel,
int value )
 

Sets the specified encoder counter to the specified value.

Parameters:
channel   Encoder channel whose value is to be set.
value   Integer value to which the encoder counter is set to.
Returns:
None.

Example: 

     setEncoderValue(1,0);
        // Resets encoder counter for channel 1 to zero.

void setEncoderIndexValue ( int channel,
int value )
 

Sets the encoder index counter to the specified value. IMPORTANT: This function might not be implemented for all I/O board servers. Pleaase check the documenation of I/O board server that you are using.

Returns:
None.
Parameters:
channel   Encoder channel whose index is to be set.
value   Integer value to set the encoder index counter to.

Example: 

     iobc->setEncoderIndexValue(1,10);
     Sets the encoder index counter for channel 1 to 10.

int getNumAdc ( void )
 

Obtains the number of A/D channels available.

Returns:
Number of A/D channels.

Example: 

     numberADchannels=iobc->getNumAdc();

int getNumDac ( void )
 

Obtains the number of D/A channels available.

Returns:
Number of D/A channels.

Example: 

     numberDAchannels=iobc->getNumDac();

double getMinDacVoltage ( void )
 

Obtains the minimum voltage that can be output to any D/A channel on the I/O board (e.g., -5 V for the MultiQ-2 and MultiQ-3 boards).

Returns:
Minimum D/A voltage.

Example: 

        minDAvoltage=getMinDacVoltage(void);

double getMaxDacVoltage ( void )
 

Obtains the maximum voltage that can be output to any D/A channel on the I/O board (e.g., +5 V for the MultiQ-2 and MultiQ-3 boards).

Returns:
Maximum D/A voltage.

Example: 

     maxDAvoltage=getMaxDacVoltage(void);

double getMinAdcVoltage ( void )
 

Obtains the minimum voltage that can be read by any A/D channel on the I/O board (e.g., -5 V for the MultiQ-2 and MultiQ-3 I/O boards).

Returns:
Minimum A/D channel voltage.

Example: 

     minADvoltage=iobc->getMinAdcVoltage();

double getMaxAdcVoltage ( void )
 

Obtains the maximum voltage that can be read by any A/D channel on the I/O board (e.g., +5 V for the MultiQ-2 and MultiQ-3 boards).

Returns:
Maximum A/D channel voltage.

Example: 

      maxADvoltage=iobc->getMaxAdcVoltage();

double getAdcValue ( int channel )
 

Reads the voltage level at the specified A/D channel.

Parameters:
channel   A/D channel to be read.
Returns:
A/D channel voltage.

Example: 

      maxADvoltage=iobc->getMaxAdcVoltage();

void setDacValue ( int channel,
double voltage )
 

Outputs a voltage to the specified A/D channel.

Parameters:
channel   D/A channel where the voltage is sent.
voltage   Voltage level to be output.
Returns:
None.

Example: 

      iobc->setAdcValue(1,3.2);
     // Sets A/D channel 1 to 3.2 volts

int getNumDiginBits ( void )
 

Obtains the number of digital input bits available.

Returns:
Number of digital input bits.

Example: 

     numDiginBits=iobc->getNumDiginBits();

int getNumDigoutBits ( void )
 

Obtains the number of digital output bits available.

Returns:
Number of digital output bits.

Example: 

     numDigoutBits=iobc->getNumDigoutBits();

unsigned char getDiginByteValue ( int byte )
 

Reads the data (1 byte long) from the specified byte position of the digital input.

Parameters:
byte   The byte position that is to be read. For the MultiQ I/O board, byte=0 with the least significant bit corresponding to digital input channel 0 and the most significant bit corresponding to digital input channel 7.
Returns:
The value of the specified byte.

Example: 

     byte=iobc->getDiginByteValue(0);

int getDiginBitValue ( int bitPosition )
 

Reads the specified bit of the digital input.

Parameters:
bitPosition   The individual bit to be read.
Returns:
0 for low, 1 for high.

Example: 

     bit=iobc->getDiginBitValue(4);
     // Reads value (high or low) of digital input line 4.

void setDigoutByteValue ( int byte,
unsigned char value )
 

Outputs the data (1 byte long) to the specified byte position of the digital output

Parameters:
byte   The byte on which the output will appear. For the MultiQ I/O board, byte=0 with the least significant bit corresponding to digital output channel 0 and the most significant bit corresponding to digital output channel 7.
value   The data to be output.
Returns:
None.

Example: 

     iobc->setDigoutByteValue(3,0xff);
     Sets all digital output lines high.

void setDigoutBitValue ( int bitposition,
int value )
 

Sets the specified bit of the digital output high or low.

Parameters:
bitPosition   The bit position to which the output is written to.
value   0 for low, 1 for high.
Returns:
None.

Example: 

     iobc->setDigoutBitValue(5,0);
     // Sets digital output line 5 low.
